App description:
Welcome to the Knockout League, a single player arcade style boxing game built from the ground up for Virtual Reality. Its intuitive gameplay involves moving and dodging with your body and 1:1 punch movement that lets you attack how you want without relying on buttons for main gameplay. Train up with various boxing drills to take on a crazy cast of characters with different fighting styles and gameplay in order to become the champion of the Knockout League!

I shouldnt have to struggle just to stand where I want to.

The tutorial fight made sense enough to me based on instructions, however, it was relentlessly unforgiving. I had many issues with the game claiming I dodged instead of blocking when I had only moved my hands up to block. My husband was in the room with me and saw I wasn't moving anything but my hands/arms. Leading to me being chastised over and over and over for my supposed "dodging".

The window of time you have to block is very small, and I found myself barely bringing my hands up before it was deemed blocking for too long by the game. The follow up of blocking and returning a punch right after had a similar issue. I was swinging as fast as I could and still wasn't good enough for the game's demands of perfection. (Before I get the dev comment telling me to hit his hand, I know. I was hitting his pad. Apparently some people didnt get that but I assure you that was NOT my problem)

Finally the nightmarish tutorial was over and though I was pretty thoroughly upset by this point I still went for the first fight. And... well. It sure didn't make up for or change much from the tutorial, aside from the absence of being consistently and repeatedly berated.

Reading through these reviews and comments has both helped and not helped. I plan to try the mini games to see if there is anything worth salvaging from this, or if asking for a refund is my only remaining option. I've never played punch out so sadly I seem to be lacking the nostalgia goggles that many others see this game in. It seems most reviews are "just like punch out, I love it" or "makes you sweat!", with the rest mentioning similar issues to what I am facing.

It's a shame the gameplay is so fickle, the art style and idea of some fun opponent characters was really appealing to me, but I felt so defeated and frustrated with the gameplay I honestly don't want to open the game up again. When I play this, I had a frown plastered on my face from 5 minutes in to well after i closed the game.

For some people this would be good I am sure, especially if you like punch out, evidently. It just is not for me.

2 stars awarded purely for aesthetics.
3 stars deducted for the gameplay and positioning issues.

Fantastic arcade boxing game

As others have noted, this is VR Punchout -- it's not a realistic boxing simulation, rather it's a series of boss fights where you learn when to effectively block or dodge, in order to have opportunities to pummel your opponent.

The cast of characters is delightfully zany, with varied styles and difficulties. The graphics are excellent and the game runs smoothly, even when the opponent has (for instance) a whole mess of undulating limbs.

It's an effective workout, having to move and punch so much, especially while learning to defeat each new opponent. Of course its replay value is affected somewhat by the fact that fighters become easier to dispatch once you've internalized their patterns and timings. Then again, there's still something satisfying in a fight you've really gotten good at. There are also some bonus training modes that can really wear you out (as if the main game didn't already do that considerably)

The whole thing is impressively polished, and I've had a great time with it. If you don't go into it expecting something like Thrill of the Fight (also a great game, in an entirely different way), and take the time to learn how to play it (if you've played Punchout it should be pretty intuitive), it will be a worthy and entertaining addition to your library. Definitely one of my favorite games.
